addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

20 N
o
1591
. M
r
Bodeleie to my L./.
The
States
consent for
e 7 compaignies goinge into
France
./

page.lettertext:
fol.211r
May it please yo
r
good L. to advertise her
Ma
tie
that after
e receat of her Hig
nes
letter
of
e 9 of this moneth, w
ch
came unto my handes
e 18 day in
e afternoone, after conference
had w
t
S
r
Francis Vere
, about
e meanes to
accomplishe her Ma
ties
pleasure, for
e further
a
ce
wherof he hath done his uttermost endevo
r
,
the next day in
e morning I presented her
letter to suche of
Holland,
as are deputed in
e absence of
e states to receave all addresses.
For
e assembly it self of
e General states
is dissolved for a time, till
e 10 of Dec
e
ber,
and every Deputy departed to his special
Province: leaving
e charge of receaving
and opening suche letters, as are directed to
e states, to some certaine of Holland: whose
autoritie doth not stretche to determine any
mater, but onely to advertise, and to make
report unto
e Provinces. Nevertheles
in this recesse of
e states, being earnestly
urged to shewe her Ma
ties
letter to
e
Councel
of state
, and to joine w
t
them in consultation,
about some order to be taken for contenting
her Hig
nes
they assembled yesternight in
e
College of the Councel, where
e letter being
read, and so muche added by me, as I thought
expedient to be spoken, it was
e opinion of them
all,
at w
t
out
e assent of their superio
rs
, to witte
of every Province, it was not in their power,
to accord her Ma
ties
demaunde. Howbeit after
fol.211v
long debating too and fro, it was resolved in
e
end, but w
t
very muche adoe, that albeit they
might not by any meanes licence those troupes,
w
ch
her Hig
nes
required to be drawen from hens,
for that it onely belonged to
e Generallitie of
e
contrey, yet they would be contented to lette
them passe by way of connivation and suffer
a
ce,
as if it were onely done by us,
at are heere
for her Ma
tie
w
t
out their liking or privitie. But
this condition was annexed, that I should un-
dertake
at
e troupes should be sent backe
againe, w
t
in
e space of 3 monethes. This
condition, I signified, was beyonde any charge
that I had receaved. Onley this I was wil-
led to promise unto them, and in her Ma
ties
behalf I did assure, that assoone as
e service
of
Rouen
and
Newehaven
is ended, whiche
in all probabilitie will be done in lesse time
then they have prefixed, ether
e self same
companies, or others in their places, should be
presently returned. As likewise I supposed
at
e other Englishe forces w
ch
were already
come to Rouen would be all revoked at a
time, wherby they should receave these com-
panies againe w
t
a rounde renforcem
t
,
and happely also some supplie for all
e rest
that are heere in her Ma
ties
pay. In
this whole negotiation, although her Ma
tie
had
willed, in case they should refuse to assent
to her demaunde, that all endevo
r
should be
fol.212r
used to effect it w
t
out them, yet because
I was not forced to signifie so muche, fin-
ding them ready to doe all
at they could, I
abstened
g
from delivering
at part of my
charge. Moreover I made no mo-
tion unto them for sending any bandes of their
owne forces, for
at of themselves I knowe
they will not, and if they would, they can
not, w
t
out
e licence of their Principals.
Howbeit for shipping for
e river of Sene,
e
Mareschal Biron
hath written very often
and earnestly unto them, and they have
already alotted 6 good shippes for
at purpose:
w
ch
I thinke are prepared to sett forward
to day.
And thus I take at this p
nt
my humble leave of yo
r
L.
From
e Hage. N
o
20 1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
If her Ma
tie
be desirous to have
these companies complete
at
goe from hens, it will be requisit
at some hundred or more be sent
out of
England
to
Diepe.
This I thought meete w
t
all
possible speede to advertise her
Hig
nes
purposing presently to
joine w
t
S
r
Francis Vere for
geving suche direction to
e
Commissary Sparhawke
, as
there may not any time be lost
for dispatche of
e souldiers.
